_link.title: I can describe the process of nuclear fusion

options: Two light nuclei combine to form a heavier nucleus
toLevel2.explanation: Nuclear fusion joins light nuclei (like hydrogen isotopes) together to form heavier nuclei, releasing energy.

toLevel2.stem: What fuel is most commonly discussed for fusion power?
toLevel2.explanation: Fusion research focuses on deuterium-tritium (D-T) reactions as they have the lowest temperature requirements.

toLevel2.stem: What is the main product of deuterium-tritium fusion?
toLevel2.explanation: D-T fusion produces helium-4 plus a high-energy neutron: D + T → He-4 + n + energy.

options: In the cores of stars like the Sun
toLevel2.explanation: Stars generate energy through nuclear fusion in their extremely hot and dense cores.

toLevel2.stem: How much energy is released in a typical D-T fusion reaction?
toLevel2.explanation: Each deuterium-tritium fusion releases about 17.6 million electron volts of energy.

toLevel2.stem: In fusion, [[light]] nuclei combine to form [[heavier]] nuclei, releasing energy.
toLevel2.explanation: Fusion joins small nuclei into larger ones, the opposite of fission which splits heavy nuclei.

toLevel2.stem: The most promising fusion fuel is [[deuterium-tritium]] which produces [[helium]] and a neutron.
toLevel2.explanation: D-T fusion has the lowest temperature requirements and produces non-radioactive helium.

toLevel2.stem: Nuclear fusion powers the [[Sun]] and other [[stars]] throughout the universe.
toLevel2.explanation: Stars generate their enormous energy output through continuous nuclear fusion in their cores.

toLevel2.stem: Nuclear fusion splits heavy nuclei into lighter ones.
toLevel2.explanation: False. Fusion combines light nuclei into heavier ones. Fission splits heavy nuclei.

toLevel2.stem: The Sun produces energy through nuclear fusion.
toLevel2.explanation: True. The Sun fuses hydrogen into helium in its core, releasing the energy that lights our solar system.

toLevel3.stem: Why must nuclei be heated to extremely high temperatures for fusion?
options: To overcome the electrostatic repulsion between positively charged nuclei
To break apart the nuclei first
toLevel3.explanation: Protons repel each other. Extreme temperatures give nuclei enough kinetic energy to overcome this Coulomb barrier.

toLevel3.stem: Why does fusion release energy according to E=mc²?
options: The products have less mass than the reactants; the difference becomes energy
toLevel3.explanation: Helium-4 has less mass than the separate deuterium and tritium nuclei; this mass defect is released as energy.

toLevel3.stem: How does the binding energy curve explain fusion energy release?
options: Light nuclei moving toward iron-56 gain binding energy, releasing the difference
Binding energy is unrelated to fusion
toLevel3.explanation: Helium has higher binding energy per nucleon than hydrogen, so fusion releases the difference.

toLevel3.stem: Why is plasma necessary for fusion?
options: At fusion temperatures, electrons are stripped from atoms, creating ionised gas
Plasma is the fuel for fusion
toLevel3.explanation: At millions of degrees, atoms are fully ionised. This plasma state is required for nuclei to approach closely enough to fuse.

toLevel3.stem: Why is deuterium-tritium fusion easier to achieve than hydrogen-hydrogen fusion?
options: D-T has a lower temperature requirement due to larger nuclei and quantum tunneling probability
toLevel3.explanation: Heavier hydrogen isotopes have higher quantum tunneling probability, requiring 'only' ~100 million degrees versus billions.

toLevel3.stem: What happens to the energy released in D-T fusion?
options: The neutron carries 80% of energy; helium carries 20%
Energy is released as light only
toLevel3.explanation: About 14.1 MeV goes to the neutron (80%) and 3.5 MeV to the helium nucleus (20%).

toLevel3.stem: Fusion requires extreme [[temperatures]] to overcome the [[electrostatic repulsion]] between nuclei.
toLevel3.explanation: The positive charges of nuclei repel each other; high temperatures provide kinetic energy to overcome this.

toLevel3.stem: The mass [[defect]] in fusion is converted to [[energy]] according to E=mc².
toLevel3.explanation: Products have less mass than reactants; this missing mass becomes released energy.

toLevel3.stem: At fusion temperatures, matter exists as [[plasma]]—ionised gas with electrons [[stripped]] from nuclei.
toLevel3.explanation: Plasma is the fourth state of matter where atoms are fully ionised.

toLevel3.stem: Fusion requires high temperatures to overcome gravitational attraction between nuclei.
toLevel3.explanation: False. High temperatures overcome electrostatic (Coulomb) repulsion, not gravitational attraction.

toLevel4.stem: Calculate the mass defect if D (2.014 u) + T (3.016 u) → He (4.003 u) + n (1.009 u).
If 0.018 u of mass is converted in D-T fusion, estimate the energy released (1 u ≈ 931 MeV).
toLevel4.explanation: E = 0.018 u × 931 MeV/u ≈ 16.8 MeV, close to the actual 17.6 MeV.

toLevel4.stem: Why does ITER (fusion reactor project) use magnetic confinement?
options: No material can contain 100+ million degree plasma; magnetic fields hold it away from walls
toLevel4.explanation: Magnetic confinement uses powerful fields to contain plasma without it touching and melting the reactor walls.

toLevel4.stem: Deuterium is abundant in seawater. Estimate the fusion energy in 1 litre of water containing 0.03 g deuterium.
options: About 300 litres of petrol equivalent energy
toLevel4.explanation: Deuterium fusion releases enormous energy per gram; 0.03g D ≈ 300 litres petrol equivalent.

toLevel4.stem: Why is achieving 'ignition' important in fusion research?
options: It means the plasma generates enough energy to sustain itself without external heating
toLevel4.explanation: Ignition occurs when fusion power exceeds losses, making the reaction self-sustaining.

toLevel4.stem: How does inertial confinement fusion (ICF) differ from magnetic confinement?
options: ICF uses lasers to compress fuel pellets; magnetic uses continuous plasma in magnetic fields
ICF uses magnets; magnetic uses lasers
toLevel4.explanation: ICF rapidly compresses fuel with lasers; magnetic confinement holds plasma for longer times.

toLevel4.stem: Why is tritium considered a challenge for D-T fusion power?
options: Tritium is radioactive with 12.3-year half-life and must be bred from lithium
toLevel4.explanation: Tritium doesn't occur naturally in useful quantities; it must be produced by neutron bombardment of lithium.

toLevel4.stem: ITER uses [[magnetic confinement]] to hold 100+ million degree plasma away from [[reactor walls]].
toLevel4.explanation: Powerful magnetic fields create a 'bottle' that contains the plasma without physical contact.

toLevel4.stem: [[Ignition]] occurs when fusion energy output [[exceeds]] energy input, making the reaction self-sustaining.
toLevel4.explanation: Ignition is the goal: the plasma heats itself through fusion faster than it loses energy.

toLevel4.stem: Tritium must be [[bred]] from [[lithium]] using neutrons from D-T fusion reactions.
toLevel4.explanation: Neutrons react with lithium blankets around the reactor to produce tritium fuel.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze why the Sun uses p-p chain fusion while reactors use D-T fusion.
options: P-p chain works at lower power density over billions of years; D-T is faster but needs higher temperatures
toLevel5.explanation: The Sun's enormous size allows slow p-p fusion. Reactors need faster D-T reactions to be practical at smaller scales.

toLevel5.stem: Compare the waste products of fusion versus fission power.
options: Fusion produces helium and activated materials; fission produces long-lived radioactive isotopes
toLevel5.explanation: Fusion waste (activated structural materials) has shorter half-lives than fission products; no long-lived actinides.

toLevel5.stem: Evaluate why fusion has been 'decades away' for decades.
options: Plasma physics challenges, material science limits, and funding uncertainties compound the difficulty
toLevel5.explanation: Confining 100+ million degree plasma while maintaining instability control and developing materials that withstand neutron bombardment is extraordinarily difficult.

toLevel5.stem: How does fusion's fuel availability compare to fission and fossil fuels?
options: Deuterium from seawater provides essentially unlimited fuel for billions of years
Fusion fuel is rarer than uranium
toLevel5.explanation: Deuterium is abundant in all water; lithium for tritium breeding is also plentiful. Fusion fuel supply is effectively unlimited.

toLevel5.stem: Analyze the safety advantages of fusion over fission power.
options: Fusion cannot melt down; any disruption stops the reaction; no chain reaction risk
Fusion is more dangerous than fission
toLevel5.explanation: Fusion plasma is so difficult to maintain that any disruption stops fusion immediately—no runaway reactions possible.

toLevel5.stem: Compare energy density: D-T fusion releases 17.6 MeV; U-235 fission releases 200 MeV. Which has higher energy per unit mass?
options: Fusion has higher energy per unit mass despite lower energy per reaction (lighter fuel)
Fission has higher energy per mass
Both are equal per unit mass
toLevel5.explanation: Per kilogram, fusion releases ~4× more energy than fission because the fuel nuclei are so much lighter.

toLevel5.stem: How might fusion power change global energy geopolitics?
options: Abundant fuel available everywhere could reduce resource-based conflicts
Only wealthy nations could access fusion
toLevel5.explanation: Unlike oil/gas/uranium concentrated in few regions, fusion fuel (seawater) is available to all coastal nations.

toLevel5.stem: Evaluate the role of private fusion companies alongside government projects like ITER.
options: Private ventures explore alternative approaches that may reach commercialisation faster
Private companies cannot do fusion research
Private and government efforts are identical
toLevel5.explanation: Companies like Commonwealth Fusion Systems explore compact designs that might commercialise faster than large government projects.

toLevel5.stem: Fusion is inherently [[safe]] because plasma disruptions [[stop]] the reaction immediately rather than causing runaway.
toLevel5.explanation: Unlike fission chain reactions, fusion's difficulty to sustain means any problem immediately ends the reaction.

toLevel5.stem: Per kilogram, fusion releases about [[4 times]] more energy than fission due to [[lighter fuel]] nuclei.
toLevel5.explanation: Although each fusion releases less energy than fission, the much lighter fuel means more reactions per kilogram.
